newsitem.title: USA: AT&T Q1 headcount up, offsetting down-sizing.
newsitem.headline: AT&T Q1 headcount up, offsetting down-sizing.

text.p: AT&T Corp said its increased hiring of customer support staff for marketing of new services and for wireless operations boosted headcount to 134,000, a net rise of 3,600 jobs during the first quarter of 1997.
The quickened pace of hiring more than offset reductions resulting from the company's ongoing, three-year restructuring plan announced January 2, 1996, the company said.
To date, 6,100 employees have left the company, primarily in backoffice, corporate support staff functions as part of the plan to reduce the workforce by 17,000 over three years.
Of the 6,100, about 3,500 accepted voluntary buyout offers, the company said.
"We have been up-sizing faster than down-sizing since the middle of last year," said Burke Stinson, an AT&T spokesman, resulting in net increases in employment during each of the last three quarters.
AT&T weathered stiff public criticism by unions and others during 1996 for the plans to slash employment levels. But newly created jobs have more than offset job cutbacks.
The company had 128,400 jobs in its continuing operations at December 31, 1995, a few days before the restructuring plan was announced. By December 1996, the total was 130,400, Stinson said.

The figures do not include staffing levels at businesses that have been sold or spun-off such as AT&T's undersea telecoms cable operations, which it sold to Tyco International Ltd for about $850 million earlier this month.
